data.title: Annual Convention Preview
data.text:
Young Guru

Audio Engineer, Producer, DJ

Gimel Androus Keaton (born February 24, 1974) better known by his stage name Young Guru, is an American audio engineer, record producer and DJ. Young Guru was nominated for a Grammy Award in 2011 for his work on "Empire State of Mind" by Jay-Z and Alicia Keys. Revered as “The Sound of New York,” Young Guru possesses over a decade of experience in sound engineering, production, and A&R for the acclaimed Roc-A-Fella Records and Def Jam Recordings. Most recognized for shaping some of the biggest talent in hip hop, Young Guru has mixed 10 of Jay’s 11 albums, and has earned himself a number of shout-outs on Jay-Z’s tracks paying homage to his exceptional skills behind the boards. Young Guru officially became Jay-Z’s tour DJ in 2010. It is an endeavor well-suited for him, considering his impeccable knowledge of Jay-Z’s discography, and their long-standing personal and professional relationship. With such a successful track record, there is no question why Young Guru is the DJ of choice, the instructor of the creative, and a producer of timeless music. Check out his blog at http://www.djyoungguru.com/blog/ and follow him on Twitter: @Young_Guru

Following a 16 year career in public service as State Senator, as Lieutenant Governor and finally as Governor of the State of Mississippi, former Governor Ronnie Musgrove now offers strategic guidance to Copeland, Cook, Taylor & Bush, Attorneys at Law and provides assistance in various legal specialties.

During his term in office, Governor Musgrove focused his attention on building a solid foundation for economic growth through Mississippi’s public schools. From the early years of his public service career when he focused on the basics of air conditioning, textbooks, health care benefits for educators, and school supply money for Mississippi’s teachers to his days as Lieutenant Governor and his successful push for quality education through adequate, equitable funding for every public school in Mississippi, Governor Musgrove changed the face of public education in Mississippi. As Governor, his commitment continued as evidenced by a teacher pay package guaranteed to meet or exceed the Southeastern average, the placement of Internet‐accessible computers in every classroom in the state (a first in the nation), and his challenge to the Mississippi Legislature to fund education first before any other budget matter, a challenge the legislature met in 2003.

During his first months in office, Musgrove led the charge to revamp Mississippi’s economic development strategies. Under his tireless leadership, Mississippi created a comprehensive approach to economic development which included reworked incentives, regional cooperation and rewarding excellence. This work paid off quickly with the location of a Nissan production facility in Canton, Mississippi, bringing a capital investment of $1.4 billion and 5,300 jobs and over 25,000 indirect jobs.

Governor Musgrove is the recipient of a Distinguished Service Award from the National Guard Bureau in Washington, D.C. He is also chairman of the National Advisory Committee on Rural Health and Human Services, chairman of the Mississippi Center for Legal Services Advisory Group and is the Senior Policy Scholar in the Department of Health Policy and Management at the Johns Hopkins University Bloomberg School of Public Health. Additionally, he has served on the faculty of the University of Mississippi and Mississippi College School of Law. Born and raised in Tocowa near Batesville, and a graduate of Northwest Mississippi Junior College, the University of Mississippi, and the University of Mississippi Law School. Governor Musgrove and his wife, Dr. Melody Musgrove, who received her masters and doctorate from the University of Southern Mississippi and who serves as Director of the Office of Special Education in the U.S. Department of Education, have four children and reside in Madison, MS. You can reach him at rmusgrove@cctb.com and learn more at www.cctb.com.

Pedro Sainz de Baranda

President, Otis Elevator Company

Pedro Sainz de Baranda is President of Otis, a position he has held since February 2012. In addition, he was appointed President, Intelligent Building Technologies, in October, 2013. Previously, Sainz de Baranda served as President, Otis South Europe and Middle East Area, a position he held since January, 2009. He joined UTC in 1993 at UTRC and transferred to Otis in 1997 as a principal engineer at the Otis Engineering Center in Farmington, Connecticut. Thereafter, he served in positions of increasing responsibility within the Otis global organization.

He earned a Bachelor’s Degree in mining engineering in Spain, a Ph.D. in engineering from Rutgers University, and an MBA from MIT where he was a Sloan Fellow. Sainz de Baranda is a recipient of the George Mead Medal for his work on the coated steel belt for the Gen2® elevator. Read his full bio that appeared in Business Week here http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=52986648&ticker=UTX&previousCapId=159264&previousTitle=Otis%20Elevator%20Company.

S. Keith Hargrove, Ph.D.

Dean and Professor of Mechanical & Manufacturing Engineering Tennessee State University

S. Keith Hargrove currently serves as Dean of the College of Engineering at Tennessee State University. He formerly served as a Department Chair at Morgan State University, and Associate Professor of Mechanical Engineering at Tuskegee University. He has worked at General Electric, Boeing, GM, and three national research laboratories (Oak Ridge, Battelle, and NIST). He is actively engaged in K12 education, and a member of the Society of Manufacturing Engineers, Tennessee Society of Professional Engineers, and ASEE. He is also a strong advocate in minority engineering education....especially the promotion and production of minority engineers and their careers. Find Dr. Hargrove on Linkedin at: http://www.linkedin.com/pub/dr-s-keith-hargrove/44/bb0/249 or email him at skhargrove@tnstate.edu

Kendall T. Harris, Ph.D., P.E.

Dean College of Engineering, Prairie View A&M University

The Roy G. Perry College of Engineering originated with the establishment of an industrial education program in 1888, and now has an established reputation for consistently graduating a large number of African American and minority engineers. Currently, the College is ranked 7th nationally in the number of all African American engineering graduates, ranked 8th nationally in the number of engineering bachelor's degrees awarded to African Americans, and ranked 9th nationally in the percentage of bachelor's degrees in engineering awarded to women. Kendall T. Harris, PhD, P.E., a native of East St. Louis. Ill, was appointed the Dean of the College of Engineering at Prairie View A&M University (PVAMU) in the Fall of 2007. Dr. Harris is the sixth dean of the College of Engineering at Prairie View A&M University.

As Dean of the College of Engineering, Dr. Harris serves as the chief administrative officer of the College in all matters related to academic, faculty and student affairs. He is also responsible for fund development, policy compliance, and student recruitment and retention.

A licensed professional engineer, Dr. Harris began his tenure at Prairie View A&M University in 2005, as Associate Dean and Professor of Mechanical Engineering. Under his leadership as Associate Dean, the College implemented the College of Engineering Success Center, which focuses on the retention of engineering students by offering supplemental instruction for freshman and sophomore students enrolled in math, science and engineering courses. He also conceptualized and facilitated a program that partners freshman advisors from each academic department within the college with advisors from the university’s freshman residence complex, University College.

Prior to joining the faculty at PVAMU, Dr. Harris served as Associate Professor and Associate Chairman for the Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering at the University of Texas at Arlington. In this capacity, he managed the departmental budget, curriculum design, fellowships, and scholarships. He graduated from the Naval Aviation Officer School as a U.S. Naval Officer and Aviator. Dr. Harris received his masters and doctoral degrees in mechanical engineering from the University of Mississippi and he holds bachelor degrees from the University of Kansas.

Dr. Harris, a devoted Christian, is married to Shundra Harris who is also an engineer, turned interior designer. They reside in Cypress, TX and have two sons. Welcome him to Nashville at ktharris@pvamu.edu

Karla Bonzie

Director, Human Resources GISC Programs Johnson Controls, Inc.

Karla Bonzie is currently Director, Human Resources GISC Programs at Johnson Controls as part of the Building Efficiency Division.

Karla Bonzie has attained 20+ years of demonstrated achievements in process manufacturing, quality management, human resources and startup business consulting. She currently works in a role supporting the Global Integrated Supply Chain Strategy and Operations Excellence organization of the Building Efficiency unit at Johnson Controls. In this role, she provides core human resource and project management services as well as business partnering to enable strategy attainment through effective human capital management.

Karla has a master’s degree in Industrial Engineering from the University of Oklahoma and has worked in the engineering filed for of much of her career. Karla believes that an engineering background provides individuals the ability to work within various roles of an organization and opens up opportunities in various industries.
